dialogue: Look at these fractions. One of them equals 1 whole.
prompt: Which of these fractions equals 1?

correct_answer.context: 2/2 equals 1 because the numerator and denominator are equal

dialogue: Look at these fractions. One of them equals exactly 1. Can you find which one lands right at the 1 mark?
prompt: Which fraction equals 1?

correct_answer.context: 3/3 equals 1 because the numerator and denominator are equal

dialogue: Look at these fractions. One of them equals exactly 1 whole.
prompt: Which fraction equals 1?

correct_answer.context: 4/4 equals 1 because the numerator and denominator are the same

dialogue: Look at these fractions. Which one equals exactly one whole?
prompt: Select the fraction that equals one whole.

correct_answer.context: 5/5 equals one whole because the numerator and denominator are equal

dialogue: Look at these fractions. Some of them equal 1. Can you find all of them?
prompt: Which fractions are the same as 1? Select all that apply.

correct_answer.context: Fractions equal 1 when the numerator and denominator are the same: 2/2, 6/6, and 8/8

success_path_dialogue: Right. When the numerator and denominator match, the fraction equals 1.

dialogue: Look at these fractions and the number line. When a fraction equals one whole, the numerator and denominator are the same. Which fractions here equal 1?
prompt: Select all fractions that equal 1.

correct_answer.context: 8/8 and 6/6 both equal 1 because the numerator equals the denominator

success_path_dialogue: Right. When the numerator and denominator match, the fraction equals 1.

dialogue: Here are two number lines showing 4/4 and 6/6. Both fractions equal 1. What do you notice about the numerator and denominator in each fraction?
prompt: Look at 4/4 and 6/6. What makes these fractions equal 1?

options.text: The numerator is bigger than the denominator

correct_answer.context: When the numerator equals the denominator (4/4, 6/6), the fraction represents all parts of the whole, which equals 1

success_path_dialogue: Yes. When numerator equals denominator, that means one whole.

dialogue: Look at these two number lines. Both 3/3 and 5/5 land at the same spot—at 1. Why do you think that happens?
prompt: Why do 3/3 and 5/5 both land at the same spot?

options.text: The numerator is bigger than the denominator

correct_answer.context: When the numerator equals the denominator (3/3, 5/5), the fraction represents one whole, which is the position 1 on the number line

success_path_dialogue: Yes. When numerator equals denominator, that means one whole.

dialogue: Look at where the points are on both number lines. What pattern do you notice about these fractions?
prompt: What do 3/3 and 5/5 have in common?

correct_answer.context: Both 3/3 and 5/5 have numerators equal to their denominators, which means they represent one whole

success_path_dialogue: Yes. When numerator equals denominator, that means one whole.

dialogue: Look at these two number lines. Both have fractions that equal 1 whole. What do you notice about these fractions?
prompt: Select the reason these fractions all equal 1.

options.text: The numerator is bigger than the denominator

correct_answer.context: When the numerator equals the denominator (2/2, 8/8), the fraction represents one whole

success_path_dialogue: Yes. When the numerator equals the denominator, that means one whole.

dialogue: Look at these two number lines. Both show fractions that equal 1. What pattern do you notice?
prompt: What pattern do you notice in fractions that equal 1?

options.text: The fraction is always less than half

correct_answer.context: When the numerator equals the denominator (4/4, 6/6), the fraction equals 1 whole

success_path_dialogue: Yes. When numerator equals denominator, that means one whole.

dialogue: Look at this bar divided into thirds. All three parts are shaded. Why does 3/3 equal 1?
prompt: Why does 3/3 equal 1?

options.text: 3 parts out of 3 total—that's all of them, which is 1 whole
Because we divided something into fourths

correct_answer.context: When all parts are shaded (3 out of 3), that represents the complete whole, which equals 1

success_path_dialogue: Right. All 3 parts out of 3 makes one whole.

dialogue: Look at the point on this number line. It's at the last tick mark, showing four-fourths.
prompt: Which statement explains why 4/4 is the same as one whole?

options.text: We have all the parts, so it makes a complete whole

correct_answer.context: When all parts are present (4 out of 4), they combine to make one complete whole

success_path_dialogue: Right. All 4 parts out of 4 makes one whole.

dialogue: Look at this bar showing 5/5. Why does having all 5 parts equal 1 whole?
prompt: What makes 5/5 equal to 1?

options.text: When you have every part, you have 1
Because it's the biggest fraction with 5

correct_answer.context: Having all the parts means having the complete whole, which equals 1

success_path_dialogue: Exactly. When you have all the parts, you have one whole.

dialogue: Look at the point at 1 on this number line. It shows 6/6. Why does 6/6 equal 1 whole?
prompt: Select the best explanation for why 6/6 = 1.

options.text: 6 parts out of 6 total—that's all of them, which is 1 whole
Because six sixths is more than five sixths
Because it's past zero on the number line

correct_answer.context: When all parts are present (6 out of 6), they make one complete whole

success_path_dialogue: Exactly. When you have all the parts, you have one whole.

dialogue: Look at this bar. All eight parts are shaded. Why does 8/8 equal 1?
prompt: Why is 8/8 the same as 1 whole?

options.text: We have all the parts, so it makes a complete whole
Because it has the most parts

correct_answer.context: When all parts of a whole are present (8 out of 8), they combine to make one complete whole

success_path_dialogue: Exactly. When you have all the parts, you have one complete whole.

dialogue: Look at these fractions. Which one equals 2?
prompt: Which of these fractions equals 2?

correct_answer.context: 6/3 equals 2 because the numerator is twice the denominator

dialogue: Look at the number line showing 0, 1, and 2. Which of these fractions would land exactly at 2?
prompt: Which fraction lands exactly at 2 on the number line?

correct_answer.context: 8/4 equals 2 because the numerator is twice the denominator

dialogue: Look at these fractions. One of them equals 2.
prompt: Which fraction equals 2?

correct_answer.context: 10/5 equals 2 because the numerator is twice the denominator

dialogue: Look at these fractions. Which ones equal 2 wholes?
prompt: Select all the fractions that are equal to 2 wholes.

correct_answer.context: 4/2 and 12/6 both equal 2 because their numerators are twice their denominators

success_path_dialogue: Yes, when the numerator is twice the denominator, that means 2 wholes.

dialogue: You know that 4/4 equals 1. Which of these fractions equals 2?
prompt: If 4/4 = 1, which fraction equals 2?

correct_answer.context: 12/6 equals 2 because the numerator (12) is twice the denominator (6)

dialogue: This number line is divided into halves. Drag the fraction that equals 1.
prompt: Drag the correct label to 1.

correct_answer.context: Two halves equals one whole

dialogue: This number line is divided into thirds. Can you drag the correct fraction label to position 1?
prompt: Drag the correct label to position 1.

correct_answer.context: Position 1 equals three-thirds because three intervals of 1/3 equals 1 whole

dialogue: Look at this number line. It's divided into fourths. Which fraction using fourths equals 1?
prompt: Using fourths, what fraction equals 1? Place it on the line.

correct_answer.context: Four-fourths equals 1 because four parts out of four equal parts make the whole

dialogue: This number line is partitioned into fifths. Can you show 1 as a fraction with fifths?
prompt: Show 1 as a fraction with fifths.

correct_answer.context: 1 equals five-fifths because five out of five equal parts makes one whole

dialogue: This number line shows sixths from 0 to 2. Drag the fraction that equals 1.
prompt: Drag the fraction that equals 1 to its position.

correct_answer.context: 6/6 equals 1 because six-sixths makes one whole

dialogue: This number line shows eighths from 0 to 2. Drag the correct fraction label to mark position 1.
prompt: Drag the correct label to 1.

correct_answer.context: Position 1 equals 8/8 because eight eighths make one whole

dialogue: This line is divided into thirds. One of these labels equals 1. Can you place it at position 1?
prompt: Using thirds, what fraction equals 1? Place it on the line.

correct_answer.context: Three-thirds equals 1, representing the whole divided into three equal parts

dialogue: This line shows halves. Drag the fraction label that equals 1.
prompt: Label position 1 with the correct fraction.

correct_answer.context: Position 1 equals 2/2 because two halves make a whole

dialogue: Look at this number line. Position 1 is labeled as 2/2. Using halves, what fraction represents position 2?
prompt: Using halves, label position 2 with the correct fraction.

correct_answer.context: Position 2 equals 4/2 when using halves as the unit

dialogue: The line shows thirds, and one position is already labeled. What fraction equals 2?
prompt: Place the fraction that equals 2.

correct_answer.context: 6/3 equals 2 because six thirds make two wholes

dialogue: Here's a number line from 0 to 2, divided into fourths. Notice that 1 is labeled as 4/4. Can you write 2 using fourths too?
prompt: Drag the fraction that equals 2 to position 2 on the number line.

correct_answer.context: 2 equals 8/4 because eight fourths make two wholes

dialogue: Look at the number line. If 5/5 equals 1, what fraction equals 2?
prompt: Show what fraction equals 2 on the number line.

correct_answer.context: 10/5 equals 2 because ten-fifths is the same as 2 wholes

dialogue: Here's a number line divided into sixths. The position 1 is already labeled as 6/6.
prompt: Drag the fraction that equals 2 to its position.

correct_answer.context: 12/6 equals 2 because twelve sixths is two wholes

dialogue: You know that 4/4 equals 1. Show what fraction equals 2 on this line.
prompt: If 4/4 = 1, what fraction equals 2? Show it on the line.

correct_answer.context: 8/4 equals 2 because it's double 4/4, which equals 1

dialogue: Look at the number line. You can see where 1/3 is marked. If that's one-third, where would 1 be? Place a point to show where 1 is.
prompt: This point shows 1/3. Where is 1? Place a point there.

correct_answer.context: Since 1/3 is one part out of three equal parts, three of those parts (1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3) equals 1 whole, which is at the third tick mark from 1/3

success_path_dialogue: Right. Three thirds make one whole, so 1 is three intervals from zero.

dialogue: Look at the number line. There's a point showing where 1/4 is. Can you find where 1 should be?
prompt: If this is 1/4, find where 1 is on the line.

correct_answer.context: One whole is four times the distance of 1/4 from zero, which is at position 1 on the number line

success_path_dialogue: That's right. Four fourths make one whole.

dialogue: Here's a number line that goes past 1. See the point at one-fifth? Use that to figure out where 1 would be.
prompt: The point marks 1/5. Click where 1 would be.

correct_answer.context: One whole is five fifths, so counting five intervals from 0 (or four more from 1/5) reaches 1

success_path_dialogue: That's right. Five fifths makes one whole.

dialogue: Look at where 1/6 is on the number line. Use that to help you find where 1 should be.
prompt: Place a point at 1.

correct_answer.context: Since 1/6 is one interval from 0, and there are 6 equal intervals to make 1 whole, the point at 1 is six intervals from 0

dialogue: You can see where one-fourth is marked on this number line. Use that to figure out where one whole would be.
prompt: This is one-fourth. Where is one whole?

correct_answer.context: One whole is four times the distance of one-fourth from zero, landing at position 1

success_path_dialogue: Right. Four fourths make one whole.

dialogue: You can see where one-third is. Use that to find where 1 is.
prompt: If this is 1/3, find where 1 is on the line.

correct_answer.context: Three thirds make one whole, so 1 is at the third tick mark from 1/3

success_path_dialogue: That's right. Three thirds make one whole.

dialogue: You can see where 1/5 is on this number line. Use that to figure out where 1 should be.
prompt: This point shows 1/5. Where is 1? Place a point there.

correct_answer.context: Since 1/5 is one interval, 1 is five intervals from 0 (five-fifths make one whole)

dialogue: Look at this number line. If this point shows 1/3, where would 1 be? Place a point there.
prompt: This is 1/3. Find 1 and place a point.

correct_answer.context: 1 is three intervals from 0, which is three times 1/3

dialogue: Now label that point with the correct fraction name for 1.
prompt: Label the point with the correct fraction.

correct_answer.context: 1 equals 3/3 because it takes three thirds to make one whole

success_path_dialogue: Right. You found 1 and named it as 3/3.
